w:r.w:t: This lesson can include a lot of props. If you have toys and games, feel free to use them as props for your student during this lesson! Your student will glean a better understanding of their toys or common toys that they play with.
At completion of this lesson, students will be able to:
Begin to learn pronunciation of short A, long A, and long I
Learn how to clap out syllables and the basics of rhyming
This slide will always be the
-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: Today, we are going to be learning and
Sing the song along with the teacher

w:r.w:t: Sing this song and work through it with your student! Have fun!
Pronounce the long A in play
Circle or underline the long A in play and pronounce
Demonstrate mouth form for long A
Circle the balls on the slide

w:r.w:t: ave a ball with you to demonstrate the difference between catching and throwing
Circle the bat on the slide
Pronounce the short A in bat

w:r.w:t: Write the word bat on the screen and circle the short A
Pronounce the short A and ask student to repeat. Demonstrate mouth form for sound

w:r.w:t: Write the word bat on the screen and circle the
Pronounce the short A and ask student to repeat. Demonstrate mouth form for sound
Match the sight word with the correct picture
by recalling “this is a…” from slide 4
Fill in the blank or circle the correct word for the sentence
Pronounce each word and read the sentence
Assist student by reading the sentence if necessary
Use TPR cues to help with word recognition
This is a ball, this is a kite
This is 3, this is 5, this is 6
Go through each of these different pictures and ask the student if they can categorize them according to whether it is a
Have the student circle or underline the different objects.
Draw a line connecting each picture while completing the sentence
Circle who and what and read the question
Repeat the question and then read the sentence, emphasis on
Emphasis on WHO and WHAT – if
draw lines from who/name and what/object
Have the student repeat after you.
Emphasize the word far and stretch to demonstrate length. Use TPR to signify its meaning.
Clap out the syllables to each of these words
Fill in the blank with the correct word:
Use TPR to prompt recall of the action verbs associated with the lesson
Count the toys on the slide
Prompt the student to count the toys
by circling the bat and counting “1”
How many ________ are there? Let’s count!
Circle/highlight the short A, long A, and long I in corresponding words to aid with rhyming
He swings on three. Count with me!

wp:docPr.name: Picture 41
wp:docPr.descr: Image result for cat baseball bat clipart

pic:cNvPr.name: Picture 144
pic:cNvPr.descr: Image result for cat baseball bat clipart

w:r.w:t: Go through this fun rhyme with the student.
Act out the swinging motion as you say the words.
Ask the student the color of each of these kites and go through the answers with them
Find and circle the red, yellow, and blue kites
Have the student circle the red, yellow, and blue kites.
check knowledge of other colors, as well.

w:r.w:t: Sung to the tune of “The Farmer in the Dell.”
Freeform “Show and Tell” Conversation Activity Slide
Student shows some of his or her toys, or talks about them
Talk about toys and see if they can show you some that they might have
Prompt using the words from the lesson – do they have a ball? What color? Etc.
Pronounce 5 of the words in the Word Wall
Prompt by circling 5 words (or more) if you have enough time.
